data.title: Bitcoin Miners Raise $11 Billion in Convertible Debt Amid AI Expansion
data.description:
According to Cointelegraph, Bitcoin miners have secured $11 billion in convertible debt over the past year as they shift towards artificial intelligence data centers. This financial maneuver follows the April 2024 Bitcoin halving, which reduced the block reward by 50%, prompting miners to explore alternative revenue streams. TheMinerMag reports that 18 convertible bond deals were completed post-halving, with major mining companies such as MARA, Cipher Mining, IREN, and TeraWulf each raising $1 billion through individual bond issues. Notably, some of these offerings featured coupons as low as 0%, indicating investors' willingness to forgo interest payments for potential equity gains.

The average size of convertible bond issues has more than doubled compared to the previous year, where most ranged between $200 million and $400 million. This shift reflects the mining industry's diversification into AI data centers to mitigate revenue losses following the halving. Miners face ongoing challenges due to tokenomics, trade policies, supply chain disruptions, and escalating energy costs. A recent report from investment manager VanEck highlights a 500% surge in miner debt over the last year, totaling $12.7 billion. Analysts Nathan Frankovitz and Matthew Sigel from VanEck emphasize that these debt levels underscore a fundamental issue within the mining sectorâ€”substantial capital expenditures on mining hardware that require frequent upgrades.

Historically, miners have relied on equity markets rather than debt to finance these significant capital expenditures, which VanEck analysts describe as a "melting ice cube." Meanwhile, Bitcoin's network hashrate continues to climb, necessitating increased computing and energy resources from miners. In October, U.S. Energy Secretary Chris Wright proposed regulatory changes to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to enable data centers and miners to connect directly to energy grids. This initiative aims to allow energy-intensive operations to meet their power demands while serving as controllable load resources for the grid, thereby stabilizing the electrical infrastructure during peak demand and reducing excess energy during low demand.

data.title: Coinbase will launch Meteora (MET) perpetual contracts.
data.description: Coinbase announced that it will launch Meteora (MET) perpetual contracts on October 30, 2025. The MET-PERP market will open at or after 16:00 UTC, provided that liquidity conditions are met and the region supports trading.

data.title: Jump Crypto Converts Significant SOL Holdings to Bitcoin
data.description: According to BlockBeats On-chain Detection, Jump Crypto has been observed exchanging a substantial amount of SOL for Bitcoin. In the last 15 minutes, Jump Crypto transferred 1.1 million SOL, valued at approximately $205 million, to Galaxy Digital. In return, they received 2,455 BTC, worth around $265 million.

data.title: Analysis: The Federal Reserve may ease monetary policy amid rising inflation.
data.description: Investment firm Aureus Asset Management's analysis points out that the Federal Reserve may ease monetary policy amid escalating inflation, with the market expecting a rate cut by the Fed at least until December. However, the risk of rising inflation remains significant. Despite all tariff negotiations, prices remain high, and there has been a growing focus on fixed income, finding its volatility can actually be reduced, rather than solely investing in stocks as in the past. (Jinshi)

In addition, this whale currently holds a long position in SOL with 10x leverage, valued at approximately $110 million, with a floating loss of $1.25 million.

data.title: Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase release previews of the Federal Reserve meetings.
data.description: Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase released their previews of the Federal Reserve meeting, including: 1. Bank of America's view on Powell and the Fed meeting: Due to limited official data and the mismatch between labor market and consumer data, Powell is unlikely to provide further economic guidance after this meeting. The statement may indicate a "robust" rebound in economic activity. Possible objections: hawkish objections from Milan (suggesting a 50 basis point rate cut) or Goolsby/Schmid. Quantitative tightening will end immediately. Powell's press conference may focus on the discrepancy between consumer and labor market data, and market reaction will depend on his interpretation of the strong consumer performance. Expected future rate cuts: October, June, September, and December 2026. 2. Goldman Sachs' comment on the Federal Open Market Committee: The market's focus may be on how close the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) is to its own policy, with quantitative tightening (QT) being crucial. This meeting is very likely to end quantitative tightening. Future rate cut plan: 25 basis point cuts each in October and December, followed by two more cuts in 2026, with a target interest rate range of 3% to 3.25%. 3. JPMorgan Chase on the Federal Open Market Committee: The market widely expects a rate cut, and even hawkish Fed officials have not disputed market expectations. The statement is expected to remain largely unchangedâ€”economic activity remains robust, but job growth is slowing and inflation remains high. Milan may oppose a 50 basis point rate cut; quantitative tightening will end immediately. Powell will define the easing policy as risk management and will not provide guidance on the policy direction in December. Future rate cut plan: 25 basis point cuts each in October, December, and January.
